mods.note: © EXT. 3955/44. Extract from G-ilgit Agency Political Diary^ for the month of July 1944. ifQ. SIHOAKG: (b) 7 Chinese subjects who had gone to India for Haj via Ladakh some years ^ ago, came to Gilgit and proceeded to Sinkiang during the month* They were in possession of travellers passports issued by the Sinkiang authorities and permits issued by the Kashmir Residency*m ^-o.\ea^T^ftl4 o C0i^^ ° oi . *84 COPY (P SQW695/10) jh' ' t 1944 , *-* C> ^ i s b“t .cc, m u r ! A. r, r':T 1 | rv^- ■ re.i-b V l I ^ Copied to: Foreign Office P.L. No.370U35H/44) of 4.4.44. ^ Government oV’ ,t Trydlar r ^Fr«~--a4:( 3/35H/44) of ^ 4 j 4.4 4. Ref: British Legation Jedda despatch No. 508/1271/13 of 7.3.44 to External Affairs Department, New Delhi. British Legation, Jedda P.L. Unnumbered of 4.4.44. British Embassy Cairo P.L. No.6(3/35H/44) of 4.4.44. His Majesty's Embassy present their compliments to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and have the honour to refer to the Embassy’ memorandum dated 24th February, 1944, communicating the contents of a report received by the Embassy from His Majesty’s Minister at Jedda, Saudi-Arabia, to the effect that a number of Chinese nationals had represented to him that they were destitute and had applied to him for assistance for their repatriation to China. His Majesty’s Minister at Jedda has now furnished details regarding nine of the destitute Chinese and a copy of these particulars is enclosed in English for the Ministry’s information. Eis Majesty’s Embassy have the honour to request the favour of an early reply in regard to this matter. BRITISH EMBASSY, CHUNGKING. April 4th, 1944.7 . r Particulars regardinp; nine destitute Chinese in Jedda. 1* Abdul G-hani Holder of Chinese passport No, 1214731 issued by Chinese Consul-General at Rangoon on 11,3,43. Came on Haj from Bombay in 1943 and holds in support of it Certificate No.2227 dated 1.5.43, issued by Public Health Department, vaccination branch, of Bombay Municipality. He belongs to Sin Kang in China. • Chinese passport No.1044407, issued by Chinese Consulate-General in Calcutta on 2.11.40. Came on Haj, as certified by P.H.C., Bombay, holder of pilgrim pass No.BF/935 dated 4.12.40. He belongs to Shinghai, Shukhashen, Kensow, China. 3. Makar a Mohammed Saleh Chinese passport No.003031, issued by Chinese Consulate at Bombay on 18.8.43. States he came with the / sole purpose of performing Haj. Belongs to Shinghai, Shukhasen, Kensow, China. 4. Abdul Ghafur Abdul Qadar Chinese passport No. 1051348, issued at Bombay on 21.5.40. Came on Haj as per endorsement of the P.H.C., Bombay, on the Chinese passport itself. Belongs to Sin Kang. 5. Ma Cheng Teh Chinese passport No.324105 issued at Chinghai in 1936. States to have come on Haj. Belongs to Chinghai. 6. Duad Mohami.ied Ali . Holds a long sheet of paper written in Chinese language, which he states is a Chinese passport. Came on Haj and belongs to Kashgar. 2. Ma Me Shihr 7. Ha.ji Hussein Saleh Holds a similar paper-as above ~~ in Chinese language. Came on Haj. • -Belongs to Kashgar. 8. .Mohammed Palto Haji Holds a pilgrim pass issued by the ? P.H.C. Karachi, shov/ing in it his nationality as Chinese. Belongs to Kashgar. Came on Haj. 9. Ha.ji Saifullah Mohammed Holder of Chinese passport , . Ho.211901, issued at.Bombay.by the Chinese Vice Consulate on May 8th, 1956.* His -passport shows that he ? belongs bo -Sinkiang in China. Came on Haj. • tobdluDu Copy. VAK< J .. (F 1438/695/10). 93 MAR IWfWer Secretary ^of State Copied to:- Foreign Office, P.L.: o. 197(2/35H/1944) Pov ernnent _India 1 X !lTo. 56 (2/35H/1944) F^a^syrGaircT pTl7 No. 5 (f2/35N/1944}. Lv ation Jedd.^ Saudi-Arabiaj v /yy^. (!) of 25th (February 1944. A I P44 7r, , His Majesty^ Nrnbafesy present their compliments to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and have the honour to state that a telegram has been received from His Majesty's Minister at Jedda, Saudi-Arabia, to the effect that about twelve Chinese nationals who have been in Mecca fqr^ many years and are now destitute have, in the absence‘of a*(^hinese representative in that country, appealed to His Majesty's Minister for assistance. They have asked to be supplied with money for their subsistence and to be repatriated to China via India. His Majesty's Embassy have been instructed by the Foreign Office in London, to whom this matter was referred, to enquire if the Chinese Government might themselves prefer to assiet these people. The British authorities concerned will of course be ready to cooperate in any way possible. The Chinese representatives at Cairo and New Delhi have been informed of the position regarding these men. The favour of a reply is requested. BRITISH EMBASSY, CHUNGKING. 24th February 1944.iX\ OUJ- Ip E-yV tc\\\V+ of. 'Sliis. -.W-'W ?? x * r / Q o o lv£d copy L. (F 6957695/10'}” (oyphi<:r) Dpty^glMT/L NO \nduu . 1. •(& FROM JKDD^ TO FOREIGN OFFICS Mr. Jordan. No. S9. D. 5.45 p.m. 4th February, 1944. R. 5.40 a.m. 5th February, 1944. v 4th February, 1944. . , v Repeated to G ov ermne nt_.jQ£,-Indianand Saving to Cairo A ' Srabassy (Mission). There are some Chinese nationals who have been stranded in Mecca for a. year and who are now. destitute. They have appealed to me for assistance as there is no Chinese representative in this country. They ask to be supplied with money for subsistence and to be repatriated to China via India. There will be ideal opportunity_in the near future for them to travel to India with some destitute Indians who are being repatriated. I consider it would be of good propaganda value to us and a courteous gesture tov/ards the Chinese Government if I could be authorised to assist these people. Their numbers are small, probably not more than twelve. Will the Government of India and Cairo please inform the Chinese representatives? I Meu. Pi. i INDIA ForeignForeign Office please pass to the Government of India as my telegram No. 14. (Copies sent to Telegraph Branch, India Office, for repetition). O.T.P.A 3 DEPARTMENTJJ, NO.l. CYPHER ] FROM J3DDA TO FOREIGN OFFICE. Mrrr'Ifordafw^ D: No.59 # 8 .: 4th February, 1£4C. Repeated to Government of India Cairo Embassy (MIs's ion). % 4* to 5 5 5 There are some Chinese nationals who have been ^ stranded in Mecca for a year and who are now destitute. They have appealed to me for assistance as there is no Chinese representative in this country. They ask to be supplied with m^ney for subsistence and to be repatriated to China via India. There will be ideal opportunity in the near future for them to travel to India with some destitute Indians j who are being repatriated. I consider it would be of good propaganda value to us and a courteous gesture towards the Chinese Government if I could be authorised to assist these people. Their numbers are small, probably not more than twelve. Will the Government of India and Cairo plea.se inform the Chinese representatives ? Foreign Office please pass to the Government of India as my v telegrara No. 14. - ' [Copies sent to Telegraph Branch, India Office, for repetition*J O.T.P.

location.physicalLocation: British Library: India Office Records and Private Papers

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the rear to the front of the file.

Foliation: the foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 11; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio.

mods.abstract: The file contains papers regarding destitute Chinese citizens in Mecca, Saudi Arabia, and potential British assistance in repatriating them via India. The primary correspondents are: British Legation, Jeddah; Foreign Office; Government of India; British Embassy, Chungking [Chongqing].
